CVE ID Acknowledgements
CVE-2017-0269 Nicolas Joly of MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations

CVE-2017-0270 - Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0270
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

An information disclosure vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could craft a special packet, which could lead to information disclosure from the server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an unauthenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


2.0    11/05/2017    

The package KB numbers for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) were transposed in the Security Update Guide for the May 2017 Security Updates Release. These package KB entries have been corrected in the Affected Products table to reflect the proper values of Monthly Rollup (4019214) and Security Only (4019216). Microsoft recommends that customers who have downloaded updates for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) verify that they have downloaded the correct package for their environment.

CVE ID Acknowledgements
CVE-2017-0270 Nicolas Joly of MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations

CVE-2017-0271 - Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0271
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

An information disclosure vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could craft a special packet, which could lead to information disclosure from the server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an unauthenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.

CVE-2017-0271 Nicolas Joly of MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations

CVE-2017-0272 - Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0272
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:8,1/TemporalScore:7,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityHigh
AvailabilityHigh
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could gain the ability to execute code on the target server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an authenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


2.0    11/05/2017    

The package KB numbers for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) were transposed in the Security Update Guide for the May 2017 Security Updates Release. These package KB entries have been corrected in the Affected Products table to reflect the proper values of Monthly Rollup (4019214) and Security Only (4019216). Microsoft recommends that customers who have downloaded updates for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) verify that they have downloaded the correct package for their environment.


 Critical Remote Code Execution

Exploitability Index

The following table provides an exploitability assessment of each of the vulnerabilities addressed this month. The vulnerabilities are listed in order of bulletin ID then CVE ID. Only vulnerabilities that have a severity rating of Critical or Important in the bulletins are included.

Temporal: 7,3

Temporal: 7,3

Windows 10 Version 1511 for x64-based Systems 4019473 (Security Update) Critical Remote Code Execution 4015219 Base: 8,1

CVE ID Acknowledgements
CVE-2017-0272 Nicolas Joly of MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations

CVE-2017-0273 - Windows SMB Denial of Service Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0273
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Denial of Service Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:8,1/TemporalScore:7,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityHigh
AvailabilityHigh
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

A denial of service vulnerability exists in the Microsoft Server Block Message (SMB) when an attacker sends specially crafted requests to the server. An attacker who exploited this vulnerability could cause the affected system to stop responding until it is manually restarted. To attempt to exploit this issue, an attacker would need to send specially crafted SMB requests to the target system.

Note that the denial of service vulnerability would not allow an attacker to execute code or to elevate their user rights, but it could cause the affected system to stop accepting requests.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting the manner in which SMB handles specially crafted client requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


2.0    11/05/2017    

The package KB numbers for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) were transposed in the Security Update Guide for the May 2017 Security Updates Release. These package KB entries have been corrected in the Affected Products table to reflect the proper values of Monthly Rollup (4019214) and Security Only (4019216). Microsoft recommends that customers who have downloaded updates for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) verify that they have downloaded the correct package for their environment.


 Important Denial of Service

Exploitability Index

The following table provides an exploitability assessment of each of the vulnerabilities addressed this month. The vulnerabilities are listed in order of bulletin ID then CVE ID. Only vulnerabilities that have a severity rating of Critical or Important in the bulletins are included.

Exploitability Assessment Publicly Disclosed Exploited
Exploitation Less Likely No No

CVE-2017-0273 Swamy Shivaganga Nagaraju of MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations

CVE-2017-0274 - Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0274
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

An information disclosure vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could craft a special packet, which could lead to information disclosure from the server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an unauthenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


2.0    11/05/2017    

The package KB numbers for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) were transposed in the Security Update Guide for the May 2017 Security Updates Release. These package KB entries have been corrected in the Affected Products table to reflect the proper values of Monthly Rollup (4019214) and Security Only (4019216). Microsoft recommends that customers who have downloaded updates for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) verify that they have downloaded the correct package for their environment.

Windows 8.1 for 32-bit systems 4019215 (Monthly Rollup)

CVE ID Acknowledgements
CVE-2017-0274 WDG Offensive Security Research Team and MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations

CVE-2017-0275 - Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0275
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

An information disclosure vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could craft a special packet, which could lead to information disclosure from the server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an unauthenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


2.0    11/05/2017    

The package KB numbers for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) were transposed in the Security Update Guide for the May 2017 Security Updates Release. These package KB entries have been corrected in the Affected Products table to reflect the proper values of Monthly Rollup (4019214) and Security Only (4019216). Microsoft recommends that customers who have downloaded updates for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) verify that they have downloaded the correct package for their environment.


 Important Information Disclosure

Exploitability Index

The following table provides an exploitability assessment of each of the vulnerabilities addressed this month. The vulnerabilities are listed in order of bulletin ID then CVE ID. Only vulnerabilities that have a severity rating of Critical or Important in the bulletins are included.

Exploitability Assessment Publicly Disclosed Exploited
Exploitation Less Likely No No

CVE-2017-0276 - Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0276
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Information Disclosure Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

An information disclosure vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could craft a special packet, which could lead to information disclosure from the server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an unauthenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.

CVE ID Acknowledgements
CVE-2017-0276 Viktor Brange of WDG Offensive Security Research Team

CVE-2017-0277 - Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0277
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could gain the ability to execute code on the target server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an authenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


2.0    11/05/2017    

The package KB numbers for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) were transposed in the Security Update Guide for the May 2017 Security Updates Release. These package KB entries have been corrected in the Affected Products table to reflect the proper values of Monthly Rollup (4019214) and Security Only (4019216). Microsoft recommends that customers who have downloaded updates for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) verify that they have downloaded the correct package for their environment.


 Critical Remote Code Execution

The following table provides an exploitability assessment of each of the vulnerabilities addressed this month. The vulnerabilities are listed in order of bulletin ID then CVE ID. Only vulnerabilities that have a severity rating of Critical or Important in the bulletins are included.

Exploitation Less Likely No No

CVE-2017-0277 Viktor Brange of WDG Offensive Security Research Team and Swamy Shivaganga Nagaraju of MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations

CVE-2017-0278 - Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0278
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could gain the ability to execute code on the target server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an authenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.

Vector: CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:L/A:L/E:P/RL:O/RC:C
 Yes None
Windows Server 2016 (Server Core installation) 4019472 (Security Update) Critical Remote Code Execution 4015217 Base: 7,0
Temporal: 6,3
Vector: CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:L/A:L/E:P/RL:O/RC:C

CVE ID Acknowledgements
CVE-2017-0278 Viktor Brange of WDG Offensive Security Research Team

CVE-2017-0279 - Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0279
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

A remote code execution vulnerability exists in the way that the Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) server handles certain requests. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could gain the ability to execute code on the target server.

To exploit the vulnerability, in most situations, an authenticated attacker could send a specially crafted packet to a targeted SMBv1 server.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how SMBv1 handles these specially crafted requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


2.0    11/05/2017    

The package KB numbers for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) were transposed in the Security Update Guide for the May 2017 Security Updates Release. These package KB entries have been corrected in the Affected Products table to reflect the proper values of Monthly Rollup (4019214) and Security Only (4019216). Microsoft recommends that customers who have downloaded updates for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) verify that they have downloaded the correct package for their environment.

CVE-2017-0279 Swamy Shivaganga Nagaraju of MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations

CVE-2017-0280 - Windows SMB Denial of Service Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0280
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Windows SMB Denial of Service Vulnerability
CVSS:

CVSS:3.0 Highest BaseScore:7,0/TemporalScore:6,3
Base score metrics
Attack VectorNetwork
Attack ComplexityHigh
Privileges RequiredNone
User InteractionNone
ScopeUnchanged
ConfidentialityHigh
IntegrityLow
AvailabilityLow
Temporal score metrics
Exploit Code MaturityProof-of-Concept
Remediation LevelOfficial Fix
Report ConfidenceConfirmed

Executive Summary:

A denial of service vulnerability exists in the Microsoft Server Block Message (SMB) when an attacker sends specially crafted requests to the server. An attacker who exploited this vulnerability could cause the affected system to stop responding until it is manually restarted. To attempt to exploit this issue, an attacker would need to send specially crafted SMB requests to the target system.

Note that the denial of service vulnerability would not allow an attacker to execute code or to elevate their user rights, but it could cause the affected system to stop accepting requests.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting the manner in which SMB handles specially crafted client requests.


FAQ:
None
Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:

Disable SMBv1

For customers running Windows Vista and later See Microsoft Knowledge Base Article 2696547.

Alternative method for customers running Windows 8.1 or Windows Server 2012 R2 and later For client operating systems:

  1. Open Control Panel, click Programs, and then click Turn Windows features on or off.
  2. In the Windows Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support checkbox, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

For server operating systems:

  1. Open Server Manager and then click the Manage menu and select Remove Roles and Features.
  2. In the Features window, clear the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box, and then click OK to close the window.
  3. Restart the system.

Impact of workaround. The SMBv1 protocol will be disabled on the target system.

How to undo the workaround. Retrace the workaround steps, and select the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support check box to restore the SMB1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support feature to an active state.


Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


2.0    11/05/2017    

The package KB numbers for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) were transposed in the Security Update Guide for the May 2017 Security Updates Release. These package KB entries have been corrected in the Affected Products table to reflect the proper values of Monthly Rollup (4019214) and Security Only (4019216). Microsoft recommends that customers who have downloaded updates for Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 (Server Core installation) verify that they have downloaded the correct package for their environment.

CVE ID Acknowledgements
CVE-2017-0280 MSRC Vulnerabilities & Mitigations and WDG Offensive Security Research Team

CVE-2017-0281 - Microsoft Office Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

(top)
CVE ID Vulnerability Description Maximum Severity Rating Vulnerability Impact
CVE-2017-0281
MITRE
NVD		 CVE Title: Microsoft Office Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
CVSS:
None
Executive Summary:

A remote code execution vulnerability exists in Microsoft Office software when it fails to properly handle objects in memory. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could use a specially crafted file to perform actions in the security context of the current user. For example, the file could then take actions on behalf of the logged-on user with the same permissions as the current user.

To exploit the vulnerability, a user must open a specially crafted file with an affected version of Microsoft Office software. In an email attack scenario, an attacker could exploit the vulnerability by sending the specially crafted file to the user and convincing the user to open the file. In a web-based attack scenario, an attacker could host a website (or leverage a compromised website that accepts or hosts user-provided content) that contains a specially crafted file that is designed to exploit the vulnerability. However, an attacker would have no way to force the user to visit the website. Instead, an attacker would have to convince the user to click a link, typically by way of an enticement in an email or Instant Messenger message, and then convince the user to open the specially crafted file.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how Microsoft Office handles files in memory.


FAQ:

The affected software table contains the link to the SharePoint Server 2013 cumulative update, KB 3191913, which includes all of the required SharePoint Server 2013 updates for CVE-2017-0281. As an alternative to installing the cumulative update, you may install the individual security updates from the following links. You must install all packages applicable to your environment to be protected from the vulnerability described in CVE-2017-0281.

3178633 3191886 3172532 3172536 3162068 3172475 3162069 3162054 3178638 3172482 3191887


Mitigations:
None
Workarounds:
None
Revision:
1.0    09/05/2017    

Information published.


1.1    10/05/2017    

Updated FAQ information. This is an informational change only.


 Important Remote Code Execution

Exploitability Index

The following table provides an exploitability assessment of each of the vulnerabilities addressed this month. The vulnerabilities are listed in order of bulletin ID then CVE ID. Only vulnerabilities that have a severity rating of Critical or Important in the bulletins are included.

Exploitability Assessment Publicly Disclosed Exploited
Exploitation Less Likely No No
